results.title: The Extraordinary adventures of the mouse and his child
results.creator_credit: Charles Swenson, Fred Wolf, Walt de Faria, deFaria-Lockhart Productions and Sanrio America
results.brief_description: This animated story of the thrilling adventures of a toy mouse and his child is based on the modern classic of children’s fiction written by Russell Hoban. From their home in the toy shop window, the mouse and his child find themselves cast into a rubbish tip where they become prisoners of the slimy rat, Manny (voice of Peter Ustinov). Helped by their friends, a fortune-telling rat, an actress parrot, a performing seal and a pink elephant, the mouse and his child plot to escape Manny’s evil clutches and discover how they can become self-winding.

results.title: The Fairy faith
results.creator_credit: John Walker, Kent Martin, John Walker Productions and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Fairies, fair folk, elves, trolls, pixies, brownies, goblins… Before being relegated to the realm of childhood fantasy by the scientific thinking of Victorian times, fairies existed as part of a rich and ancient belief system practised in many cultures. Filmmaker John Walker investigates the continued appeal of fairy lore in a world obsessed with materialism and rational thinking in this beautifully filmed documentary filled with the stunning landscapes that have fuelled tales of fairy folk for generations. He travels to the moors of England, the Highlands of Scotland, and sacred sites within Ireland and Cape Breton, discussing the origins of fairy lore, sightings of “the little people” and modern attitudes to the fairy faith. Walker interviews artist Brian Froud and reveals the inspiration for his fairy artworks, discusses the reality and physical possibility of fairies with scholar in seeing the paranormal Dr. Mark Fox, and meets Eddie Lenihan, a storyteller who saves an old fairy thorn tree from being destroyed by town developers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Walker, Kent Martin, John Walker Productions and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Experiment = Das Experiment
results.creator_credit: Oliver Hirschbiegel, Fritz Wildfeuer, Marc Conrad, Norbert Preuss, Fanes Film, Senator Film Production and Typhoon Pictures
results.brief_description: In his directorial debut Oliver Hirschbiegel brings together a taut drama based on a novel by Mario Giordano (“Black Box”) about a human behaviour experiment. Offered 4000 marks, 20 men are recruited for a two-week experiment where they will role-play either prison inmates or guards. A journalist Tarek (Moritz Bleibtreu, of “Run Lola Run” fame) working mainly as a taxi driver takes part wearing high tech video-recording glasses. Once roles are assigned, uniforms are put on - militaristic ones for the guards and a simple numbered smock for the prisoners - and the rules for the experiment are made clear. Like a ‘Lord of The Flies’ but for adults locked in a cage with similarly shocking results - after only three days things go awry and the corruptible nature of power in the human psyche asserts itself. Dark and industrial setting with hard-rock sound track (‘Linkin Park’ are featured) add to the oppressive and harsh environment in which the story takes place. Cast includes Maren Eggert, Christian Bekel, Justus Von Dohnany and Oliver Stokowski. Bleibtreu won Best Actor for this role at two film festivals.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Oliver Hirschbiegel, Fritz Wildfeuer, Marc Conrad, Norbert Preuss, Fanes Film, Senator Film Production and Typhoon Pictures

results.title: The Face of the high Arctic
results.creator_credit: Dalton Muir, Hugh O'Connor, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A study of the geological evolution that has gone on for millions of years. Treeless wastes bear evidence of glaciers that advanced and receded, and of life forms that changed with the climate. The film tracks the cataclysmic forces that passed over this Arctic land.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dalton Muir, Hugh O’Connor, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Australia Felix
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
A man of many talents, Major Mitchell is credited with discovering an otherwise unknown area of Western Victoria that he referred to as “Australia Felix”, or “Happy Australia”. Over his four costly expeditions, Mitchell was asked to confirm that the Darling River ran into the Murray and to see if there were any undiscovered surrounding areas. Motivated by a passion to disprove Sturt, who had traversed the region before him, Mitchell earned the wrath of Governor Darling and society as a whole thanks to the massacre of blacks at Mt Dispersion. A man of many contrasts, Mitchell was responsible for naming the Grampians, Glenelg River and Discovery Bay. He received a state funeral upon his death.

results.title: East to north
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
Presented by Bill Peach, this program uses reenactments to describe the trail taken by the expeditions of Ludwig Leichardt from the eastern settlements in New South Wales north to Port Essington in Northern Australia, documenting the challenges and hardships they faced along the way.

results.title: Prison walls
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
Using historical documents and footage as well as dramatised re-enactments, Bill Peach describes the epic journey of Blaxland, Wentworth and Lawson as they crossed the Blue Mountains and discovered the lush pastures on the other side. This video also explores the reasons why the expedition was carried out and the impact the discovery had on the growth of the young colony of New South Wales.

results.title: The Secret of the Murray
results.creator_credit: Richard Walker and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
Dramatised documentary written and presented by Bill Peach recounting the exploration of New South Wale’s river system. In 1828, Charles Sturt, a young English army captain lacking formal qualifications or practical bushman skill, was chosen to explore Australia’s western rivers. Hamilton Hume was appointed second in charge of the expedition and provided the guidance and support that enabled Sturt to unlock the secrets of Australia’s rivers and explode the myth that Australia was a giant basin with its waters draining into an inland sea. His greatest feat was charting the course of the Murray River to the sea. Sturt was an ambitious man who never achieved the high rank that he desired. In an act of ambitious flattery he named the Murray river after the Secretary for the Colonies rather than recognise the discovery made by Hume and Hovell.

results.title: The Evil one
results.brief_description: As the hunters return from their hunt, the tribe gathers around the fire to hear stories of the Dreamtime. In this story Marmoo, the Evil one tries to abduct two children and make them his slaves, but after a long chase they are rescued by the Winjarning Brothers, spirits from the heavens, who defeat Marmoo in an epic battle of minds which leaves Marmoo as an ant which then dies. An imaginative recreation of this Aboriginal legend, narrated by Belza Lowah.

results.title: Overland to Port Phillip
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
Using dramatised re-enactments and historical documents, Bill Peach describes the overland route from Sydney to Melbourne which was originally discovered by Hume and Hovell. This route still survives as the Hume Highway.
